# JavaCPP_r1
_Created for the course "Cross-platform programming" V. N. Karazin Kharkiv National University_

JJava 11 program for modeling the calculation of a function and its derivative, which is specified by a formula or table.

The source codes of the classes can be found in _r1\src\_

___

The programme consists of 2 versions. Version 1 is in the consoleTasks package, version 2 in the refactorConsoleTasks package. Version 2 of the programme is a revised and improved version 1, to improve code readability, support and extensibility of the programme.

# package refactorConsoleTasks

`Evaluatable` interface guarantees that an object of a class that implements this interface can calculate the value of one given argument using the `double evalf(double x)` method.

The `FFunction` class implements the Evaluatable interface and is designed to evaluate a function by formula: 

![image](https://github.com/DarkCard1nal/JavaCPP_r1/assets/34416583/86993c2a-eb8c-4b84-b431-f8e58cc672fb)

Constructors:

`FFunction(double a)`

`FFunction()` - sets `a` = 1.0.

Methods:

`double getA()` - returns the value of the parameter `a`.

`void setA(double a)` - sets the value of the function parameter `a` to the specified value.

`static void main()` - method for testing the class.

The `Point2D` class is derived from the `Point` class and implements the `Comparable` interface. This class creates, saves, a collection of points of 2-D space (its x and y coordinates), and the overridden method `int compareTo(Point2D pt)` allows you to sort lists of such collections by `x`.

Constructors:

`Point2D(double x, double y)` - a collection with a point of coordinates `(x, y)`

`Point2D()` - a collection with a coordinate point `(0, 0)`

Methods:

`double getX()`

`void setX(double x)`

`double getY()`

`void setY(double y)`

`static void main()` - method for testing the class.

The abstract `Interpolator` class implements the `Evaluatable` interface, performs the function of interpolating data, regardless of how it is stored and represented, while the children of this class are also functions and implement the `Evaluatable` interface.
It overrides the `double evalf(double x)` method, which implements the calculation of the interpolation Lagrange polynomial using a set of specified points for the specified argument.

Abstract undefined methods:

`void clear()` - clears the list of points.

`int numPoints()` - returns the number of points in the list.

`void addPoint(Point2D pt)` - adds a new point to the list.

`Point2D getPoint(int i)` - returns the point with index `i`.

`void setPoint(int i, Point2D pt)` - sets (replaces the existing) point `pt` to the location with index `i`.

`void removeLastPoint()` - removes the last point in the list.

`void sort()` - sorts the list of points.

The `ListInterpolation` class is derived from the `Interpolator` class, overriding its undefined methods.

Constructors:

`ListInterpolation(List<Point2D> data)` - recreates a list of points from data.

`ListInterpolation()` - creates an empty list of points.

`ListInterpolation(Point2D[] data)` - recreates a list of points from data.

Methods:

`static void main()` - method for testing the class.

The `FileListInterpolation` class is derived from the `ListInterpolation` class, reproduces and interpolates the function specified in a table from a text file with the definition of the absolute error, generates and writes function `sin(x)` to a text file. As a result of the work, we will get the text files `"data.dat"` (intermediate stage of testing), `"TblFunc.dat"` (final file for use in the programme).

Constructors:

`FileListInterpolation()` - constructor of the superclass.

Methods:

`void readFromFile(String fileName)` - reading a table function from `fileName`.

`void writeToFile(String fileName)` - writing a table function to file `fileName`.

`static void main()` - method for testing the class and creating the final file `"TblFunc.dat"`.

The `DerivativeFunction` class that will implement the `Evaluatable` interface and return the derivative of the function using the `evalf()` method. 

Constructors:

`DerivativeFunction(Evaluatable function, double accuracy)` - creates a function that is derived from `function` and calculates the derivative with an accuracy of `accuracy`.

`DerivativeFunction(Evaluatable function)` - calls the constructor `DerivativeFunction(function, 1.0e-4)`.

Methods:

`static void main()` - method for testing the class.

Overrides the `evalf()` method, which returns the derivative of the `Evaluatable function` with an accuracy of `double accuracy`.

The `DerivativeApplication` class is the main class for launching the application and contains only the `main()` method, which performs all the necessary actions to launch and test the program according to the task. The table function is read from the file `"TblFunc.dat"` previously generated by the `FileListInterpolation` class. In this class, an array of objects that implement the `Evaluatable` interface is first declared. Then the elements of the array are created - functions defined in different ways and their initialization is performed: a function that is defined in a table reads values from a table that has been previously saved in a text file. You should pay attention to the conversion of the reference variable type for an array element that contains a reference to a function - a solution to an equation. This was done in order to take advantage of the object methods that are not available in the `Evaluatable` interface. Next, for each function in the array, tabulation and calculation of the derivative are performed.





# package consoleTasks

`Evaluatable` interface guarantees that an object of a class that implements this interface can calculate the value of one given argument using the `double evalf(double x)` method.

The `FFunction` class implements the Evaluatable interface and is designed to evaluate a function by formula: 

![image](https://github.com/DarkCard1nal/JavaCPP_r1/assets/34416583/86993c2a-eb8c-4b84-b431-f8e58cc672fb)

Constructors:

`FFunction(double a)`

`FFunction()` - sets `a` = 1.0.

Methods:

`double getA()` - returns the value of the parameter `a`.

`void setA(double a)` - sets the value of the function parameter `a` to the specified value.

`static void main()` - method for testing the class.

An abstract `Point` class that contains an array of coordinates to represent a point in an n-dimensional space with basic capabilities. Overrides the `String toString()` method to return a string of point coordinates in the format "(x, y, ..., n)". 

Constructors:

`Point(int num)` - sets the number of spaces.

Methods:

`void setCoord(int num, double x)` - sets the value of `x` (coordinate) to space `num`.

`double getCoord(int num)` - returns the value of the coordinate of space `num`.

The `Point2D` class is derived from the `Point` class and implements the `Comparable` interface. This class creates, saves, a collection of points of 2-D space (its x and y coordinates), and the overridden method `int compareTo(Point2D pt)` allows you to sort lists of such collections by `x`.

Constructors:

`Point2D(double x, double y)` - a collection with a point of coordinates `(x, y)`

`Point2D()` - a collection with a coordinate point `(0, 0)`

Methods:

`double getX()`

`void setX(double x)`

`double getY()`

`void setY(double y)`

`static void main()` - method for testing the class.

The abstract `Interpolator` class implements the `Evaluatable` interface, performs the function of interpolating data, regardless of how it is stored and represented, while the children of this class are also functions and implement the `Evaluatable` interface.
It overrides the `double evalf(double x)` method, which implements the calculation of the interpolation Lagrange polynomial using a set of specified points for the specified argument.

Abstract undefined methods:

`void clear()` - clears the list of points.

`int numPoints()` - returns the number of points in the list.

`void addPoint(Point2D pt)` - adds a new point to the list.

`Point2D getPoint(int i)` - returns the point with index `i`.

`void setPoint(int i, Point2D pt)` - sets (replaces the existing) point `pt` to the location with index `i`.

`void removeLastPoint()` - removes the last point in the list.

`void sort()` - sorts the list of points.

The `ListInterpolation` class is derived from the `Interpolator` class, overriding its undefined methods.

Constructors:

`ListInterpolation(List<Point2D> data)` - recreates a list of points from data.

`ListInterpolation()` - creates an empty list of points.

`ListInterpolation(Point2D[] data)` - recreates a list of points from data.

Methods:

`static void main()` - method for testing the class.

The `FileListInterpolation` class is derived from the `ListInterpolation` class, reproduces and interpolates the function specified in a table from a text file with the definition of the absolute error, generates and writes function `sin(x)` to a text file. As a result of the work, we will get the text files `"data.dat"` (intermediate stage of testing), `"TblFunc.dat"` (final file for use in the programme).

Constructors:

`FileListInterpolation()` - constructor of the superclass.

Methods:

`void readFromFile(String fileName)` - reading a table function from `fileName`.

`void writeToFile(String fileName)` - writing a table function to file `fileName`.

`static void main()` - method for testing the class and creating the final file `"TblFunc.dat"`.

The `NumMethods` class contains only static numeric methods for calculations and a private constructor.

Methods:

`double der(double x, double tol, Evaluable f)` - numerically differentiates the function `f` at point x with an accuracy of `tol`.

`static void main()` - method for testing the class.

The `DerivativeApplication` class is the main class for launching the application and contains only the `main()` method, which performs all the necessary actions to launch and test the program according to the task. The table function is read from the file `"TblFunc.dat"` previously generated by the `FileListInterpolation` class. In this class, an array of objects that implement the `Evaluatable` interface is first declared. Then the elements of the array are created - functions defined in different ways and their initialization is performed: a function that is defined in a table reads values from a table that has been previously saved in a text file. You should pay attention to the conversion of the reference variable type for an array element that contains a reference to a function - a solution to an equation. This was done in order to take advantage of the object methods that are not available in the `Evaluatable` interface. Next, for each function in the array, tabulation and calculation of the derivative are performed.


# Testing
For testing, in accordance with the terms of the task, the values of the interval `x∈[1.5, 6.5]` with a step of `0.05` for several test functions of the function value and its derivative are used.

As a result of testing, the values obtained by the program coincide with the true values of sufficient accuracy (double number type, taking into account the inaccuracy of calculations and conversions). The results of the program are saved to the corresponding text files `"FFunction0.5.dat"`, `"FFunction1.0.dat"`, `"FFunction1.5.dat"`, `"FileListInterpolation.dat"`, these files can be viewed in any text editor, or used in programs similar to Microsoft Excel to build tables and graphs.

Based on these files, we created graphs in the third-party software Microsoft Excel. The graphs generated coincide with the theoretical ones, which means that the program calculates the function and derivative correctly (with acceptable accuracy).
![image](https://github.com/DarkCard1nal/JavaCPP_r1/assets/34416583/d0a43c39-c7c4-423d-b938-07a85109f1f1)
![image](https://github.com/DarkCard1nal/JavaCPP_r1/assets/34416583/0b2314dd-bb42-4285-9874-b1e9731b203c)
![image](https://github.com/DarkCard1nal/JavaCPP_r1/assets/34416583/1929be4b-d96b-435a-85e7-d9c1bfb2c103)
![image](https://github.com/DarkCard1nal/JavaCPP_r1/assets/34416583/956370b8-b353-4a5e-a148-3b60376265c8)
